title: minerjones
author: minerjones
content: PCGS is now grading redeemed Casascius coins in these new slabs.

comments.author: Suzuki Matt
comments.body: Wow that's cool they did that.

comments.author: Spokanistan51
comments.body: Cool as a display piece, but not a fan of the private key being exposed

comments.author: Steeley
comments.created_time: October 24, 2022, 07:04:31 PMLast edit: October 24, 2022, 07:17:05 PM by Steeley
comments.body: This looks very cool, but I‚Äôm not sure I understand fully. This appears to indicate that they remove the redeemed, but previously intact, hologram? If so, why? ¬†Is this so they can better grade the reverse? Do they feel like there is a liability to intact redeemed holograms? Regardless of their reasons, this is a serious move on their part that seems to indicate a high level of commitment to grading physical bitcoins. Wow

comments.author: minerjones
comments.body: Quote from: Eclipse33 on October 24, 2022, 07:32:37 PMQuote from: Steeley on October 24, 2022, 07:04:31 PMThis looks very cool, but I‚Äôm not sure I understand fully. This appears to indicate that they remove the redeemed, but previously intact, hologram? If so, why? ¬†Is this so they can better grade the reverse? Do they feel like there is a liability to intact redeemed holograms? Regardless of their reasons, this is a serious move on their part that seems to indicate a high level of commitment to grading physical bitcoins. WowSomebody at PCGS is sipping the Kool-aid. This is a massive step and shows somebody at PCGS is taking these seriously. Yes, the holos were both partially attached... came as a surprise when I opened the box.In thought this seems to remove them from the liability of someone later claiming it was supposed to be loaded...But I guess you could peel a coin and not redeem it, but then the private key would be exposed

comments.author: BTCOVERFIATS
comments.body: Why does it matter if the private key is exposed if the coin is already redeemed and never going to be loaded again? The worst thing that can happen is they see your transaction history, but they can already do that since they have the public address.....

comments.author: Steeley
comments.body: Quote from: BTCOVERFIATS on October 24, 2022, 08:06:33 PMWhy does it matter if the private key is exposed if the coin is already redeemed and never going to be loaded again? The worst thing that can happen is they see your transaction history, but they can already do that since they have the public address.....This was my reaction too. It would be crazy to peel a holo but not actually redeem the value. The private key is just an artifact of the collectible at that point.

comments.author: inelasticsupply
comments.body: These gping to be auctioned? Curious what you think the 5btc is worth?

comments.author: minerjones
comments.body: Quote from: inelasticsupply on October 26, 2022, 01:16:51 AMThese gping to be auctioned? Curious what you think the 5btc is worth?Not sure.. these were submitted on behalf of another collector and they approved me posting the pictures.Redeemed 5's are pretty rare to come by... plenty of the blanks out there.I could see this go for in the 0.1 range if marketed properly

comments.author: JUPITYR
comments.body: Not a fan of the separate coin and holo.¬† Just my 2 Satoshis.

comments.author: Spokanistan51
comments.body: All valid opinions and feedback. For those who have no issues with the private being exposed, ask yourself if you would willingly show your peeled coin private key on here, for example? Most probably would not. Even if swept, there is still a privacy aspect in my view of them not being visible.

comments.author: BTCOVERFIATS
comments.body: But what can you possibly hide by not exposing the redeemed private key? They already have the public address. We can go to any block explorer and see where the coins ended up with that public address...There is zero risk of having the redeemed private keys on Casascius coins exposed IMO. I'm specifically talking about Casascius private keys, not ones generated on your own.

comments.author: SFR10
comments.body: Quote from: minerjones on October 24, 2022, 07:38:34 PMYes, the holos were both partially attached... came as a surprise when I opened the box.I'm curious to know if they took the time to clean the sticker residue or just left everything in that state?- I do know that normally it's not their job, but it'd be quite strange to see the latter one.Quote from: BTCOVERFIATS on October 24, 2022, 08:06:33 PMWhy does it matter if the private key is exposed if the coin is already redeemed and never going to be loaded again? The worst thing that can happen is they see your transaction history, but they can already do that since they have the public address.....You have a point, but there are other risks apart from its privacy issues:e.g.You still have to trust them to not claim the remaining forked coins!You're basically giving someone else the ability to sign a message with it [apart from the manufacturer that generated it] and if there's any kind of history attached to the public address in question, then it could go wrong in some ways!- I do know it's a very specific situation that probably isn't going to apply to most users, but still...

comments.author: CARIBBEAN_TREASURES
comments.body: I love this set up. I have a bunch of keys I've been wanting to do something with. It's perfect.
